We laughed it off. Time to order. I asked how big the Gazpacho was because I was considering getting that and a salad for lunch instead of one larger dish. The dry answer: "it's an appetizer." Really? I can read and didn't see it was under "starters," how'd you know? Thanks. So I just went with the salad. For two salads, two appetizers, and espresso, our business lunch took 2.5 hours because we had to wait so long for the check. Being a new "hot spot" in town I would have understood if it was as bustling as one would expect, but it was pretty dead. Maybe they were annoyed we weren't a big ticket table and wanted to freeze us in their blasting A/C in retaliation. I don't know. Not impressed. At least I expensed it.

Food was great but the waiter spent over 20 minutes chatting to the table next to us while we were waiting to order more drinks. We were the only other group in the dining room and were ignored for a long time. Heard that the restaurant is separate from the hotel, so still hold the Edition in high regards. Great atmosphere and I want to return, but aghh hire better staff/train them!!!!

The BF & I had dinner last week at The Clocktower, an ultra-cool restaurant with a great & unique ambiance.  While waiting for our table, we enjoyed nice cocktails at the bar while people-watching (they even have a pool table!).  Their warm, crispy bread loaves are outstanding.  A perfect crunchy crust with a hot, soft doughy center - it was so good we asked for another loaf!  I had the Big Eye Tuna Tataki for my appetizer and the Long Island Duck for my main.  The BF had the Steak Tartare for his appetizer and the Rabbit & Foie Gras as his main.  We enjoyed all of our plates; however I think he would have opted for a different main entrée.  We also had ordered a side of French fries (which they had forgotten at first) - served thick/English-style cut.  We decided to skip out on dessert, but they had brought some lovely mini complimentary treats (brittle, salted caramels, & shortbread cookies).  Although I don't need to come back to The Clocktower for more than another drink, I am glad I was able have that dining experience!

KenScale: 8.5/10British cuisine has always been neglected in the gastronomic world, falling way behind French, Spanish and Italian counterparts in the rankings of European cuisine. I've never heard about people going to London for culinary journey, and I haven't seen any place in NYC that really shows what British cuisine is all about. That changed recently when acclaimed English chef Jason Atherton formed a partnership with a famed restrauteur Stephen Starr to open The Clocktower inside the chic Edition hotel. I was overall very pleased with the dining experience on a recent Friday night. There is nothing fussy about the food at The Clocktower. They seem somewhat predictable if you just skim through the menu. The level of execution and balance of flavor and texture of most dishes, however, were on a very high level. I could eat lobster with shaved fennel, mussel and apple salad every day for my meal. Lobster was perfectly cooked with crunchy texture to my delight, and the unexpected combination with apple salad worked quite nicely. While I was expecting a bit more spice from North African spiced Colorado lamb, it still was a perfectly cooked lamb dish that wasn't overpowering in seasoning to my liking. Some dishes fell somewhat flat. I was puzzled why uni risotto with peekytoe crab tasted a bit on the sour side, and thought it would've been a perfect dish if not for that sour seasoning. Braised halibut was perfectly cooked and created intense flavor with pink peppercorn sauce. I did like the spicy kick from the sauce, but felt the seasoning could've still been toned down a bit. Both desserts that I tried, on the other hand, were marvelous. I've never had pistachio-flavored soufflé before, and the combination of the soufflé with chocolate ice cream was pure bliss, with silky smooth texture of warm soufflé working wonders with the cold sensation of ice cream. "Strawberries and cream" dessert that consisted of vanilla custard, olive oil cake and verjus sorbet was also quite delightful with its elegant flavor without being too sweet. The Clocktower is one of the hottest spots these days (not just for food but for its throwback-style décor that would make for a hip and pleasant dining experience), so make sure to book early. I loved the classy yet energetic vibe coming from the restaurant. The restaurant has full bar menu (with some creative cocktails coming from the bar area next to the dining space). The Clocktower is a welcome addition to the New York dining scene with its introduction to what sophisticated British cuisine would look like.
The food was delicious and beautifully presented! Service was good but a bit slow.
Amazing food. Loved the pigeon pie and the pistachio soufflé is definitely worth the 20min wait.

Loving this restaurant at the recently opened Edition Hotel in NYC. We came here for lunch on a Saturday and the food and atmosphere were beyond incredible. It is a little tricky to get into the restaurant if you haven't been there before, but if you look for signs or ask for help you should be okay. Don't skip dessert here as the mix of sorbets and ice cream are sublime and the presentation is fantastic.

fantastic new upscale place in NYC. immediately rocketed up my list of favorite restaurants for a splurge.the space itself is really nice; up a spiral staircase to 3 dining areas, a billiard room, and a bar. early 20th century paneling and mirrors give a really warm old school new york feel, which is only enhanced by the plethora of b&w photos, ranging from NYC scenes to celebrities, crowding the walls. it's a compelling mix of casual and elegant. we arrived early, and went to the bar for cocktails while we waited. lovely marble bar, small without feeling crowded. 1st thing the bartender did was ask if we were waiting for a table, and when we said yes, she took our name, so they could watch for when our table was ready. this was the first indication of how well thought out their service is. meghan had a gin/lemon/dill cocktail that was bright and grassy, i had a rum/maple thing that was comforting without being heavy. yum. it was a birthday dinner, so we pulled out all the stops (as if we don't usually pull out all the stops). we started with a dozen oysters, 3 east coast varieties. all super fresh and tasty. for appetizers we had an salad -English breakfast radishes, salad leaves, cucumbers, feta and pistachio purée, that was capricious and playful, with an unexpected citrus gelee, and a mini pigeon pie with , Waldorf salad, celeriac,& sauce diable. this was recommended by our waiter, and it was tremendous. maybe the best single taste of the night. they also have an uni risotto and a steak tartar with marrow and mustard leaves that i really want to go back and try.for our mains we had Macaroni and cheese, with morels & slow-cooked ox cheek, which is more delicious that it sounds, and it sounds delicious. the macaroni was a large rigatoni sort of pasta, which allowed the cheese to line its inside surface in a very delightful way, and we had Rabbit and foie gras w/ Lancashire hotpot, heritage carrots, Parma ham, & tarragon oil. this was really 2 dishes, slightly disconnected by the plating, but that's a minor quibble when compared to just how delicious it was. the 1st part was rabbit loin and foie gras rolled together, and wrapped with prosciutto cotto, on a plate with carrots and some bitter greens (i love carrots with rabbit - it's so what's up doc) and next to it was a tall ramekin with rabbit and small sliced potatoes in a deep rich sauce. The menu has a duck breast that is supposed to be really good, real dover sole, and an interesting looking lamb with N. African spices. (yes i plan on going back and trying all this stuff, at some point)we had a bottle of Lo Vièlh Carignan - from Le Clos du Gravillas in Languedoc. not overly complex, really smooth and drinkable. the wine list is pretty extensive (and expensive) herefor dessert we had "Strawberries and cream"- vanilla custard, olive oil cake, verjus sorbet, which was excellent, fresh and creme and a great light dessert, and Grapefruit sorbet, curd and suprèmes, hazelnut streusel, fennel marmalade, which was really bright, if slightly disjointed.the service was smooth, and proper, without ever feeling stuffy or staid. the staff was well trained, friendly, and everyone was open to help out, and check on how it was going. for a restaurant that is only 2 months all, the kinks are remarkably well worked out, and they are clearly hoping to build a following. i hope they do, this place deserves to last.TL;DNR - lovely room, great food, excellent service. not cheap, but well worth the splurge

Fantastic food in a sophisticated setting.  The 'cold fashioned' bourbon cocktail eases you into this place and gets you ready. Food wise, the steak tartare topped with roasted bone marrow is a great way to start.  And the dry aged burger topped with cheese, pickles, onion and Churchill sauce is the ultimate adult Big Mac.

Fun and unique space on the 2nd floor of a fancy Marriott, The New York Edition?! Either way still a cool space with fun food and drinks.  Good vibe and very good looking staff male and female. Interesting take on Mac'n cheese. We did have a fire alarm and announcement blaring thru our second course but it was still a good time.

Great ambiance. Excellent food. We had a few drinks at the Gold Bar before dinner. Drinks were very good. The staff is very professional. I had oyster appetizer and the filet for main course. Both were excellent. Highly recommend!

This is an "in" restaurant in NYC right now. The Edition hotel recently opened and The Clocktower is the perfect excuse to swing by and check out the new digs. Most of the restaurant kept the original decor of the building and it gives the impression that the restaurant has been there for decades. The food was surprisingly good. We shared several things to start. The memorable items were the spring leaf salad  and the steak tartare. I did not love the Alaskan king Crab. I ordered the Colorado lamb for my main and while it was good, I was a little surprised at the smaller size of the racks, especially since they were from Colorado. Service was friendly and efficient and the highlight of the meal was at the end when they brought a tin with shortbread and toffee!! I would return just for these sweet bites!

Came by here for happy hour with my fiancé.  The place smells like someone overdosed on Jo Malone oil diffusers and I love it.  The crowd is trendy and well polished so to speak. I grabbed a couch near the fireplace that fits two and ordered a few cocktails. She had the rose wine and I had a cocktail that had ginger but I cant remember the name.  I will definitely be returning back here to try the restaurant out.

Swanky, hot new resto of the moment and it hit the mark for me. Three separate dining rooms w/old Hollywood photos adorn the walls. Sounds a bit cheesy, but the decor totally works. Mixed crowd...couples, bankers, B&T...seems like everyone wants to check this place out. Wine list definitely pricey, but a really nice list and settled on a lovely French red which didn't completely break the bank. (Extra points for having my fave rose, which is from a small producer in Italy.) Food was excellent. Scallops and tuna tartar to begin. Scallops served alongside cauliflower accompaniments and the tuna was served as bite sized pieces w/cucumbers. Both delicious. Skirt steak was a nice size and cooked perfectly (and eaten on really nifty plates w/skulls on them). Came w/great chips (fries) and a side salad. Pork chop was big and juicy, served w/delicious beets. Strawberries and cream for dessert...very different interpretation...light, yet decadent.  Complimentary cookies (shortbread was so yum!) are served in an old fashioned tin when the check arrives. Service was great all around...from water guys to main waiter to the somm and host...good stuff. All in all, a very enjoyable night out and look forward to returning. Side note: check out the cool billiard room and back bar for an after dinner drink before heading home!

My favorite restaurant for the past 4 years in NYC has been Gramercy Tavern. Then I walked into the Clocktower and everything changed. From the moment we walked in to the moment we walked out, we were in awe. Everything was incredible. The decor of the space is beautiful, the bar has a great setup and there is even a room for the pool table. And a huge huge shoutout to the general manager who was so wonderful and attentive and to Bryn who made our entire experience 10x better. Unlike many other top notch restaurants that have very rigid staff, the staff at this restaurant has the perfect balance of elegance and friendliness. Now onto the food... WOW. Appetizers: Steak Tartare - Yes, this wonderful dish comes with bone marrow. If you didn't think steak tartare could get any better, you are mistaken. This was perfect. Asparagus - This dish was heavenly. You have the consistency of the egg perched on top of the asparagus mixing with the chicken thigh and the result is pure bliss. Add on the chicken jus that is poured on top from a chicken container, and you have the perfect dish.Entrees:The Duck - Ohhh that wonderful, wonderful duck. Cooked to perfection. There is nothing else to say but yes.Macaroni and Cheese - This dish comes with Ox Cheek, you read that correctly.. ox cheek. The balance of the meat with the pasta and cheese was incredible. This is definitely a dish that you must try!Desserts: Strawberries + Cream - delicious! light, fluffy and airy - this dessert was a perfect ending to a perfect meal. Apple tarte tartin - If you are an apple lover, then look no further. This is it. This is the pinnacle of desserts for you - it will never get better than this. And how about those drinks! Check out the incredible cocktails menu. Our drink came in a milk carton and had bourbon and cheerios milk (yes actual milk from cheerios). It was strong and delicious. Some of the other drinks came with friendship bracelets, glow sticks, etc... What more can be said? This is my new favorite restaurant in NYC and definitely my new go to. I'm just afraid of what is going to happen when the word gets out and the press lets the world know of this incredible place! Reservations definitely will be much harder to come by. Definitely go!

Wow!! A near perfect meal... We had great Bread, a very fresh perfectly seasoned Beef Tartare with Bone Marrow, a very nice Uni Risotto, a perfectly executed Duck A L'Orange, and a truly delicious Mac & Cheese made with Morels and Beef Cheeks. For Dessert, a stunningly perfect Apple Tarte Tatin for two, a la mode.  And the atmosphere and service were cool, not at all stuffy.  This chef really knows how to make people's tummies happy....The British are coming, indeed...

Chic but somehow you still feel at home. The servers are beyond friendly but not overbearing. I came before there was a brunch menu but would come back and try it. The burger is meaty and delicious. All the toppings complement nicely to make a nice juicy burger. It's pricey just like most of the menu but the atmosphere is chic and cool that the price tag is more justifiable. Friend had the salmon and it was perfect. It was also one of those plates where you definitely eat with your eyes first. They also have a cool bar room.

This week's fashionplate is a brunch time edition at The Clocktower at  Ian Schrager's Edition Hotel.  The restaurant is located right by the Credit Suisse building on Madison and 24th.  The restaurant is located on the second floor of this luxe and modern hotel, take the winding egg-like staircase or the elevator to arrive to multi-room British inspired mens clubhouse. I met my dining companion at the bar and he was already drinking a martini, hey it was 2.  We then were seated in one of two dining rooms in a  sumptuous chartreuse booth and I decided on trying the American Cereal Killer cocktail that comes in the cutest little milk carton glass.  It's a delicious bourbon based cocktail that tastes like a decadent dessert.  I ordered the burger medium rare with chips and my companion had the tuna tataki as he was staying on the liquid diet.  The burger was perfectly cooked and juicy with a great proportion of bacon and cheddar.  The chips were amazing, I'm going to come back for happy hour and have those with cocktails.  His tuna was a nice and light starter.We ordered more cocktails and spent the rainy afternoon gossiping, drinking and eating and enjoying the cozy setting.  As this was a summer weekend, it wasn't packed but the patrons were a mix of hotel guests and mostly late twenties and thirtysomething couples looking for cover on the rainy day.

I wish I could leave a nicer review for this place but I just couldn't. I was super excited about this place because it's part of EDITION hotel. I just love Ian Schrager and the design looks superb. Went for a lunch with a friend. Food is okay, I mean, it's ENGLISH, what can you expect? Portion is small but quality is generally okay. We liked the King Crab and the chips. Skirt steak was nice too. The service, meh. I wouldn't even call it service. I'm not sure if it's because this place is relatively new and the personnel training is still ongoing - we were served by a couple different people and I couldn't figure out who's in charge of us until someone came over asking if the meal is okay. More than 5 waiter/waitress in the dining room serving probably less then 20 ppl and it's a mess. Our waiter kept forgetting the orders - my friend wanted a refill of hot water of her tea, he forgot it and we had to ask another person who was avaiable; when we finished the meal I asked for a coffee and I waited about 10 mins, this person brought us the dessert menu and  did not even ask if we'd like to have dessert (I already ordered coffee!!!), just laid down the menu on the table and walked away, without even talking to us! How rude!I asked, again, another lady to bring me a cup of coffee. Coffee is good, then, I asked, with my best patience, if I could get a refill...he said yes and forgot to refill me, for a THIRD TIME IN A ROW. Then I was pissed, very much. I just couldn't believe what we've experienced. I'd like to believe he's just new to the place. But again, if this was the case, I wouldn't put this person on duty. The two stars, one for the deco/design; half for the kind people who helped - a lady who looks like the manager was very nice and there was another gentleman who's been helping all the time; half for the food. But I am not going back. This is a restaurant affiliated to a 5 star hotel and it is certainly not the service I'd expect. This is New York and for the same price you can def get better stuff - if you want hotel restaurants in particular, go to Narcissa at Standard East Village or Juni at Chanlder Hotel. Oh the cloest option would be Maialino at Gramercy Park Hotel.
Came here on a Sunday date night. The portions were generous for the price point. Great meal overall. The crab with fried uni is a must try. The cocktails looked interesting but they tasted ok.

I went in for a group lunch, and it was a very cool experience overall. The ambiance is chic and has the vibe of a hip British pub. The food was also excellent and creatively presented. The cocktails include random ingredients like chicken stock or buttermilk, which I wasn't sure what to make of. People at the table who ordered cocktails had rave reviews though.The green circle chicken breast entree was surprisingly amazing- the chicken was very tender and it came with a delicious chicken jus. The uni risotto was good, but slightly too pungent and salty.I must say that my favorite part was the dessert - the strawberries and cream and grapefruit sorbet are both highly recommended! They also provide a cute metal tin of complimentary desserts filled with shortbread, toffee, and chocolate-covered brittle at the end of the meal. All were amazing as well. This place lives up to the hype and is worth checking out!

One of my favorite meals, in stunning surroundings. Convective takes on classic dishes. Even the cocktails are full of whimsy and flavor. Christopher was a phenomenal server, also regaling us with tales of going to Delmonico's.

This place is the real deal!  I love a good hotel restaurant because they usually  know how to take care of "guests", aren't too stuffy and have great hours....open almost all of the time!  We stopped in for brunch and were so pleased from start to finish.  The decor and history of the restaurant are awesome and they've done a great job with it.  The management is top notch and incredibly welcoming and the food is amazing!  You must try the gnocchi with spring vegetables....one of the best I've had!  The crab thermidor was also fab. Huge pieces of fresh crab on toasty bread, so good!  The best thing we had may have been the strawberries and cream dessert.  So delicate and delicious!  They also brought a small set of dessert bites that included one of the best shortbread cookies I've ever had, a homemade marshmallow and some candies.  Such a nice touch.  The Clocktower is a new favorite!

One word about this place. Fantastic. The food is amazing, service is great. U really feel special here. I don't get why people r so mean on the rating while giving it so much positive feedback. The bread, appetizer, entrees all the way to the desserts are great from start to finish. The chefs here really put in love and care into the dishes. U can feel the love! Come and see for urself. Take a loved one here and enjoy yourselves.

It is amazing all around, from services, decor to food.Why it is not 5 stars? creativity.Came here on a Monday night and the bar is bustling. Very good sign. A mix crowd from out-of-towners staying at the Eition Hotel to finance guys working in the hood. Dining room is gorgeous. Main dinning room has enormous Victorian-style fireplaces and walls covered with 500 black and white photos of the city and iconic New Yorkers. It is perfect setup for a first date or a business dinner. To start, I went with the American Cereal Killer. An innocent looking drink with a deadly punch! Made of Mitcher's whiskey.\, cheerios milk, Madagascan vanilla syrup , angostura bitter, served in a cute milk carton. It is easy to sip at first and potent after taste. Not a girly drink and I love it! Onto the food. We got the uni risotto with peekytoe crab, bottarga and zesty yuzu peel. It is creamy and savory , the citrus flavor from yuzu really stands out and a good contrast. But somehow not as harmonious as I hope. Prob better decorated with nori instead?Come along the risotto, roasted diver scallops, ragout of line caught squid, crepe , bacon in celery root purée. It is savory tho a tad too salty to my taste. The scallops are perfectly cooked, soft and juicy.Again, not bottom-shaking but it is well executed. Fave tonight! Long Island duck, sauce l'orange with fennel, endive and salt baked turnips . It is amazing. The bird is cooked medium rare while the skin is crisp, the muscle is juicy and scrumptious. The sauce is fragrant and just the right sweetness and consistency. The turnips are the best part which soaked up the #duck juice and sauce. Beautiful presentation. Service is attentive and each dish was introduced in details. That's what fine dining should be.Considering my office is close by, I will stop by every now and then, even just for drinks.

I will make this scientific :)Ambiance=9 (very chic)Sommelier= 1 (failed to answer questions about the vineyard or region multiple times, we opted for cheaper wine for spite)Apptz= 7 (had the scallops)Main = 9 (the King Salmon was excellent)Dessert=3 (the Souffle was a disaster and the Tartine was basic)Service=7 (basic and nice, but again nothing that merits any exceptional service)I am waiting a year before I decide if its worth reconsideration

This beautifully decorated restaurant was a delicious brunch experience. Aside from a miscommunication with the server which I didn't deduct stars since they remedied it appropriately but removing an item off the bill, we had a nice dining experience. The bread which isn't served for brunch is delicious. Served pipping hot, it has a hint of sweetness to it. The butter served on a wooden hair pick is velvety smooth. The steak tartare is very flavorful. They take a bone marrow and scrape it right on top of the steak tartare. Yum!The burger is very good. We ordered it medium rare. The condiments of thinly slicked pickle, lettuce, red onion and their sauce stayed well in place surprisingly so it wasn't a sloppy meal. The king crab sandwich is buttery good with a creamy bisque like spread. The fried are amazing; perfectly crisp and thick. They end your meal with complementary dessert consisting of marshmallow, butter cookie, chocolate peanut toffee and caramels- all homemade!

A great new restaurant in the city. The scene is definitely hot and loud. The decor clubby with interesting retro photographs. Service is attentive but not intrusive. The scallops were perfectly cooked and tasty. Cornish fish stew was like a deconstructed bouillabaisse featuring tasty bits from the sea. The portion could have been a little bigger. The pistachio soufflé with chocolate sorbet was amazing. Light with a nutty fragrant finish and then rich chocolate to balance it off. Overall outstanding.

Wow Wow Wow!!!! I love Edition hotels, I have been to them in Istanbul and Miami, I have to say this is by far my favorite one!  The lounge downstairs has a cozy fire and the bar is just perfect. Ok, enough with the hotel...it's all about Clocktower for this reviewWe walked up the circular staircase to the restaurant and  the moment I saw it, I was in love. I really appreciate how they divide the dining rooms, this means less noise and more intimacy. There is also a bar to the side, which looks like great date spot!The food was simply amazing, I had the white asparagus as an appetizer and only let my boyfriend have 1 bite.....I'm selfish when it is that good : )My entree was the lamb and it was cooked to perfection. My boyfriend had the filet  mignon and he was very silent while eating....which means he loved it.Wine list is grand and eclectic. 2 thumbs upMy only complaint is do not come here if you are very tired, the dark lighting and dark wood design/smell may make you drowsy. Maybe i'm totally off on this remark, but i did find myself yawing a few times, an espresso fixed that though!I highly recommend eat, drink and enjoy!

Came here four days into the opening of this restaurant, my friend knew about it but due to low advertising, I hadn't heard of it. I really liked the vibe, the photos on the wall and the dim lite. Standouts would be the service and steak tartare with bone marrow. Oysters come out looking nice but they werent extraordinary, scallop crudo was a bit fishy to me. Nice touch is a tin box at the end that reminds you of Grandmas house and is filled with various goodies. Bravo-lebritisa and celebs were there during my time. I would love to come back for the tartare and sit at the bar.

In all fairness, this place is just getting it's legs so I'll try and go easy.The staff is very nice. Was hour wait so we grabbed a drink in the bar. Only one drink as the bartender takes about 20 min. per concoction, but the waitress was very nice and exchanged the adventurous "pollos hermanos" drink I tried and didn't like at all.Personally, the appetizers were my favorite. Although they took an eternity, as did the mains, the lobster salad was great and the tuna tataki was even better. I would suggest they add a little ponzu or similar to the lobster salad, as we were dipping it in the tuna sauce and not the mayo it came with.Again, took about an hour for our entrees to arrive and the place wasn't that crowded around 930. We were fine waiting but man they better get that time cut in half!I ordered the salmon rare and it came out medium/well. A very nice piece but I was not impressed at all with the "parsely chowder." I'm not a fan of mint flavors in my food and this had a hint of mint so it was a bit of a downer. A mustard or champagne sauce would be much better.The lamb was cooked great but again I was not impressed by the sauce. Call me crazy, but I like what I like and this place - at least for now - misses the mark with those two dishes and the really long waits. However, the grapefruit sorbet is to die for and the waiter brought out all 6 flavors for us to try due to the long wait time so that was nice. the combo chocolate and vanilla are awesome, too.

Beautiful and classy restaurant with immaculate dishes.Cote de boeuf - a delicious bone-in ribeye cut with fatty, marbled, and bone-in sections. Bone marrow jus was the perfect complement to this steak, without overpowering the natural flavors at all. Grilled garlic was a great touch. Tip: pair with the Grenache red for an awesome experience. Colorado lamb - cooked to perfection, ideal tenderness. So tasty on its own and even better with the innovative combination of condiments and vegetables on the plate - eggplant, yoghurt, curried onions, perhaps cucumber and a rich sauce?King Salmon - the salmon was also cooked perfectly. Crispy skin and firm exterior with a "medium rare" interior than almost melted in your mouth. I don't like peas much. But the black garlic purée was a great addition.Roasted sea scallops - one heck of an appetizer. There were so many good ideas in this dish and it all came together in a blaze of gastronomic delight. Lobster salad - I don't know how but the apple slices complemented the light, fresh taste of the lobster excellently. Not the typical heavy butter taste.Steak tartare - tasty. Their thin bread crisp puts a spin on the traditional toast.The restaurant has a classy, dark wood interior and boasts a pool room next door to boot. Great for brushing up on your pool skills whilst waiting for apps.

Uhhhh....yes yes and did I mention YES?Friends of mine were visiting from Miami (where there is also an Edition Hotel) for MDW and informed me that an Edition Hotel opened in NYC recently and that they wanted to have dinner there. I had no expectations and was blown away.The staff was welcoming, knowledgeable, and actually acted like they enjoyed working there. I hope that over time this won't fade...+ My water was constantly re-filled throughout the night and the staff seemed on point. AmbianceDark wood and perfect lighting. Need I say more? Very romantic vibe yet also could see business dinners conducted here. There are two rooms directly next to each other but yet separated so each room feels very intimate. We sat next to Fredrik Eklund (from Million Dollar Listing) so I assume a lot of "celebrities" will be pouring into this hotel.Wine+ They have great options for all price points. I was really surprised at the range. I wasn't let down as I had the Austrian wine (Gruner Vetliner, which I seem to find on every menu in NYC which leads me to ask who the hell is their wine rep?!) and it was yummy yet very inexpensive. FoodI ordered a salad to start. I can't remember the exact name of the salad and can't seem to find their menu anywhere online but basically it was just a mixed green salad with a light yet fruity vinaigrette dressing. The salad was excellent. I'm not usually a fan of paying a large amount of money to eat lettuce and I seem to always find that the dressing portion applied to salads are either too heavy or too light.Thiswasperfect.A really light and refreshing way to start my meal. I would say this is a MUST ORDER.I followed the salad with the uni risotto despite it being listed as an appetizer. I was still a bit hungry after the salad and risotto but not too bad. I wasn't in the mood for a huge entree and wanted a smaller portion for dinner as I had a late lunch. It was quite tasty and I would definitely order it again. It was a tad too creamy for my taste (I'm lactose intolerant yet still consume a lot of dairy, don't ask) but nonetheless was very good. My friends had the filet mignon (which was cooked perfectly) and the chicken (which she loved).+ I was impressed with how on point the experience was from start to finish despite it being a brand new restaurant.I definitely will throw this restaurant into my rotation!

Recently opened, this is a new restaurant from the Starr Group.  It is in the Edition Hotel at the clocktower of the former Met Life building at 5 Madison Park.  The space is paneled with an eclectic gallery of photographs of artists and celebrities.  The music is trendy.  The Goldleaf bar is a half round bar next to the  Pool table and is warm and inviting.  Service was good and very friendly.  Drinks range from 8-16 for the most part.   Dinner was in adjacent rooms with similar sort of decor.  One room has a fireplace.  Service was over the top and very accommodating and attentive.  Food was excellent and presentation was great.  I tried a few dishes including the lobster, the risotto and the radish salad.  I also ordered the bone in Sirloin Steak.  While all the dishes were very good the Uni Risotto was a stand out.    The Steak was perfectly cooked and very tasty.   Prices are on par with fine dining restaurants.  This is a wonderful place to go for a romantic dinner or a business dinner or just a drink after work.  Definitely they are going for the Michelin star so time will tell.   Check it out before it gets too busy.

We were there on opening night. I understood that they already had a soft opening . We had 6:30 dinner reservations and got there a few minutes early. They offered us a seat at the bar and then actually seated us at a small tall table within the bar area. We ordered drinks, and before the cocktail waitress made it back to our table, the restaurant hostess came to tell us our that our table was ready and they would bring the drinks to our table in the restaurant. We sat down and our delicious drinks were delivered in less than a minute. A word about the decor. It's a beautiful place with art on all the walls up to the ceiling. There are two bar rooms, one with a pool table. It would and probably will be a nice place for drinks only without actually dining. By the way, maybe because it was their first night, but it looked to me like there were twice as many workers as needed, thus the over the top service. Food: scallop appetizer, for my wife and chilled lobster for me. Both very good and adequate portions. 14 oz. NY strip for me and lamb chops for her. Done to perfection and very flavorful. Apple tart with vanilla ice cream for two to finish our meal. Note this is a nice place and the food was great, we were there for almost two hours and yet the check came to $203.00 before the tip. Not a bad deal for Saturday night in New York City. Upon leaving my wife asked me if we could come back next week.

Came on the opening night.  Ambience, service and food are all amazing.  The cocktails are creative,  nice and more importantly, taste great.  We were seated in the American Room.  Started with the American Cereal Killer cocktail which is Bullet Burbon and milk and Give Peas A Chance cocktail.Starters were Steak Tartare...probably one of the best I have had in a long time and Uni Risotto. Main was Pork Belly and Bone Marrow as well as Cornish Fish Stew. We will definitely return!
